conversation.content: Look. I had an account. Years ago. Need my stuff back.
I can—no wait, let me just—okay, I can absolutely help you recover those purchases. Um, do you remember the email address you used for that account? I'll need to verify with our system code VAL-8823.
It was... what's the word... deactivated? Deleted? Something like that.

Oh, hmm, so even if an account was deactivated, your purchase history should still be in our database under reference ID DB-PURCH-7749. Er, when you say deleted though—did you delete it yourself or did we?
You did. Said inactive too long. That's what they told me.

*exhales* Ah, yeah, I know, it's ridiculous that we do that. So basically after 24 months of inactivity, the system auto-archives accounts under protocol P-2294, but—and this is important—we can actually still recover everything.
That's what the last person said. Three calls. Still nothing.

Ugh, I'm really sorry you've had to call multiple times about this. Let me try—actually, hold on—I'm going to use a different recovery tool, access code REC-TOOL-9B4. Sometimes the standard process just doesn't, um, work properly.
Right. So what's... what's different about this one?
Got it.
Got what? You found something?

So I can see—*sharp inhale*—oh wow, I can see your entire purchase history here under legacy account L-88392-KJM. There's, er, quite a bit actually. Would you like me to transfer everything to a new account or reactivate the old one?
Wait. You actually found it? Like... everything's there?

Mmm-hmm, everything. I'm looking at, let's see, 47 digital purchases dating back to 2019, all linked to customer ID C-LEGACY-2847. Honestly? The other reps probably just didn't check the archived database.
Okay so... how do I... what's the process here?

Right, so what I'll do—er, actually, what would work best for you? I could either send a reactivation link to your current email with verification code VER-8829-XK, or I could manually transfer everything right now.
Transfer. Now. Before something else goes wrong.
*exhales* Yeah, I don't blame you for wanting it done immediately. Alright, initiating transfer protocol TRN-4498-LIVE, and I'll stay on while it processes, probably about two minutes.
Two minutes. Okay. And then I'll have... everything back?

Absolutely everything, yeah. Your new account number will be ACC-NEW-7739-BK, and honestly? I'm also adding a note to prevent any future auto-archiving, because this whole situation is just—it shouldn't have been this hard.

scenario: trying to recover access to purchases made on old account
